Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Holocene Megadroughts of the Central Great Plains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Historic droughts, like those of the 1930s and 1950s, had severe social, economic, and environmental ramifications for the Great Plains. They were, however, transcended by the more severe and geographically extensive prehistoric megadroughts of the Holocene. Under these massive drought conditions, vegetation cover was diminished, and soils succumbed to erosive winds, causing the widespread mobilization of dust and sand deposits, which mantle much of the Great Plains.

Doctoral student Alan Halfen under the guidance of Professor William Johnson in the Department of Geography at the University of Kansas will determine periods of prehistoric megadroughts in the central Great Plains, thereby better defining patterns of past droughts. The chronology of prehistoric droughts will be determined by dating drought-sensitive sand dunes in the Arkansas River valley, southwestern Kansas, using optically stimulated luminescence (OSL). This dating method, which determines when individual sand grains were last exposed to the sun, will provide reliable ages of dune activity and attendant drought conditions. The dune field will also be analyzed to assess its mineralogical maturity, a relative indicator of landscape age. Mineralogical maturity provides information regarding dune sediment provenance, transport history, and weathering history of a dune field. Lastly, periods of dune activity will be compared to similar studies elsewhere in the Great Plains to identify spatial and temporal patterns of prehistoric drought.

Given that climate models have predicted increased temperatures and decreased precipitation in the Great Plains this century, this study will further enhance our knowledge of patterns of past drought and will provide vital paleoclimatic data to better calibrate existing climatic models. This study promotes diverse collaboration between academic institutions and government agencies, and enhances the education of undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used geomorphic methods to reconstruct the history of prehistoric megadroughts from sand dunes in the Arkansas River valley of the Central Great Plains. Prehistoric megadroughts were widespread droughts much more severe than historic droughts such as those of the 1930’s Dust Bowl. Climate models have projected higher temperatures and decreased precipitation on the Great Plains during this century, which may lead to the return of regional megadroughts. This research has helped to better articulate the climate-landscape relationship of the region, thereby better equipping society to cope with future climate change and resultant landscape responses.

The timing of prehistoric megadrought activity in the Arkansas River was developed using optical dating, a dating technique which determines the last time a sand grain was exposed to sunlight. Optical dating is ideal for dating prehistoric megadrought activity from Great Plains dunefields because, during drought conditions, vegetation cover is diminished, and soils succumb to erosive winds, causing widespread blowing of dust and sand. Optical dating captures the timing of this dune activity and, therefore, can determine periods of past megadroughts.

The Arkansas River dunes appear to have first formed from sediment deposited by the Arkansas River about 16,000 years ago under northerly winds. These dunes are similar in morphology to those found in modern desert dune systems, which indicates that these dunes were formed under high wind velocities and abundant sediment supply, possibly during megadrought conditions. While data from this project do not show when dune activity about 16,000 years ago stopped, other data from the study site suggests it may have occurred about 12,000 years ago.

Our data also suggest the Arkansas River dunes reactivated several times during the Holocene in response to megadrought activity, including at least once prior to 4500 years ago, and several times within the last 2000 years. Significant dune activity is documented about 1000 years ago, including as recently as within the last 500 years. This dune activity, as has been hypothesized in other Great Plains dunefields, may be the result of megadroughts, which were documented to have occurred during the Medieval Climatic Anomaly (about 1100–700 years ago) and Little Ice Age (about 600–200 years ago). Finally, our data also document historical dune activity, which occurred during the megadroughts of the 1930s and 1950s.

This research has made significant contributions to the disciplines of geography and geomorphology largely because this project is the first comprehensive investigation of dune activation in the Arkansas River valley. Additionally, data from this project have provided a fresh perspective on the severity and extent of prehistoric megadroughts within the Central Great Plains. Further, data from this project have also been used to improve the academic settings at the University of Kansas. Specifically, information on the formation and timing of dunefields in the Arkansas River valley have been incorporated into introductory and upper-level geography classes as a case study of regional paleoclimatic and landscape change.
